bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to L.O. Howard, February 11, 1918

div1.p: Carter writes that he cannot help now because the war has stopped his mosquito research.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to L.O. Howard, February 11, 1918
div1.opener:
/LC
February 11, 1918.
Dr. L. O. Howard,
Chief of Bureau of Entomology,
U. S. Department of Agriculture,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Howard:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of February 8/18, relative to
Culex peribleptus. I would say that the war has stopped all of
my research work as such and turned my efforts to control of
malaria in extra cantonment areas. We do not expect then again
to take up the problem of Impounded Waters until the war is over.

I will, however, keep your letter on file and when this
problem is again taken up, by myself or someone else, get you
the material you want.

I am exceedingly sorry to hear of Dr. Knab's illness as
I have always had the very highest esteem for him.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
